docs.lead_paragraph: HCA Inc., the health care chain, said today that a federal appellate court had overturned fraud convictions against two former executives. The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta reversed the convictions of Jay Jarrell and Robert Whiteside on Friday, HCA said. They were found guilty on six counts each in July 1999, as part of a fraud investigation against the company.
docs.abstract: Three-judge federal appeals court overturns 1999 Medicare fraud convictions against former HCA Inc executives Jay Jarrell and Robert Whiteside, only HCA executives convicted in probe of health care chain; HCA paid $840 million in fines and penalties to settle related criminal and most civil charges; case focused on reports to Medicare by HCA's Fawcett Memorial Hospital, Port Charlotte, Fla (M)
docs.snippet: HCA Inc., the health care chain, said today that a federal appellate court had overturned fraud convictions against two former executives.    The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta reversed the convictions of Jay Jarrell...

docs.lead_paragraph: BY the time the dismissal bells ring in the public schools throughout New Jersey on Tuesday, educators will have a much clearer idea how much the more than one million students in the state will suffer because of a yawning budget deficit. The 600 school districts in New Jersey have already been told that they would probably receive the same amount of direct aid from the state for the 2002-3 school year as they did in the current year -- $5.8 billion, of which almost half will go to the poorest districts.

headline.main: Who Will Feel the Pain In This Budget Squeeze

docs.abstract: Article assesses possible impact on New Jersey public school students as result of state budget squeeze; school districts face hard choices in light of increasing enrollments, skyrocketing number of special education students and increases in insurance and transportation costs; state pays average of 40 percent of school budget, with about half going to 30 poorer districts; affluent districts receive less than 10 percent of funding from state; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Experts have long attributed the race gap in medicine to lack of insurance for minorities. But a study by the Institute of Medicine found that even insured minorities get lower-quality health care than whites. Nonwhite patients were less likely to have heart bypass surgery or kidney transplants, for instance, while nonwhite diabetics are more likely to have limbs amputated. The reasons include differences in the quality of health plans and the fact that white patients tend to have longer relationships with primary care physicians, as well as subtle racial bias, said the authors, who termed their findings a wake-up call to doctors. Sheryl Gay Stolberg

headline.main: March 17-23: NATIONAL; RACE GAP IN HEALTH CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: BILL SCHACHTER, an instructor in a new Westchester County program for older job seekers, begins his class by whipping out photographs of his grandchildren. At 72, Mr. Schachter, who is frequently older than his students, understands physical as well as emotional hurts, including the frustrations of trying something new. In this case, in his classroom at the Westchester/Putnam One Stop Employment Center here, it's tackling the computer, a difficult and often scary undertaking for an age group ill at ease in a high-tech world. In the first five minutes he has broken the ice, created neutral ground. The students bring out their photos, of their grandchildren.
docs.abstract: Article on new peer program at Westchester/Putnam One Stop Employment Center in White Plains, NY, aimed at helping older workers gain new work skills; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the fighters in the battle over how much state aid goes to many of the public schools is Dr. Kenneth D. Hall, president of the Association of the Middle Income School Districts. The 300 districts in New Jersey that usually receive 30 percent to 60 percent of their budget money from the state often suffer the most because unlike the state's 125 wealthiest districts, their residents are less able to afford the increase in property taxes to make up for the lack of state financing.

headline.main: One of the Leaders in the Battle To Pry Loose Aid for the Schools

docs.abstract: Article on role of Assn of Middle Income School Districts president Kenneth Hall in seeking increases in state aid to New Jersey school districts caught in budget squeeze; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BRACE yourselves. If you receive Social Security benefits or assume that you will one day -- Republicans and Democrats are about to barrage you anew with claims, counterclaims, promises and warnings about the fate of the retirement system. They will have a common theme: that the other side is seeking to embark the nation on a path that will leave the government unable to meet its obligations to the elderly.

headline.main: Lockbox or Not, Social Security's Ills Grow

docs.abstract: Richard W Stevenson column assesses Democratic and Republican claims and counterclaims about long-term financial soundness of Social Security and how it relates to federal budget and 2001 tax cut; says Republican approach of adding personal investment accounts to program will not by itself solve financial shortfall and that Democratic plan amounts to hoping for return to budget surplus; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of the Travelers insurance business rose just less than 6 percent yesterday in their first day of trading, disappointing some investors. Traveler's parent, Citigroup, sold 21 percent of the commercial insurance unit in an initial public offering on Thursday at $18.50 a share. The shares rose $1.06, to $19.56. They were the most actively traded for the day on the New York Stock Exchange, with about 75 million shares changing hands.

headline.main: On First Day, Travelers Shares Are Up 6% in Heavy Trading

docs.abstract: Shares of Travelers insurance business rise just less than 6 percent in their first day of trading, disappointing some investors (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Many Doctors Shun Patients With Medicare'' (front page, March 17) accurately detailed the very painful decision some physicians must face to limit the number of new Medicare patients they accept. During the last 11 years, Medicare reimbursement payments to doctors have risen an average of 1.1 percent per year, while doctors' costs have increased an average of 2.4 percent per year. Although the federal government supports health care for the elderly, doctors must ultimately determine whether they can afford to stay in practice when Medicare reimburses them less and less for the cost of treating patients.

headline.main: Medical Questions: The Care, and Paying for It

docs.abstract: Letter from American Academy of Family Physicians president Dr Warren A Jones says March 17 article accurately detailed painful decision some physicians must face to limit number of new Medicare patients they accept; says during last 11 years Medicare reimbursement payments to doctors have risen average of 1.1 percent per year, while doctor's costs have increased average of 2.4 percent

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bad Medicine,'' by Paul Krugman (column, March 17): As a practicing internist for more than 30 years, I believe that two critical health care questions need to be addressed: Where is the health care dollar going? And are we getting quality care for each dollar spent? For example, the fear of malpractice results in excessive, costly procedures, like numerous CAT scans and M.R.I.'s and excessive laboratory testing.

headline.main: Medical Questions: The Care, and Paying for It

docs.abstract: Dr Harvey I Hurwitz letter, commenting on Paul Krugman's March 17 Op-Ed column on problems affecting nation's health care system, says two critical health care questions need to be addressed, namely, over how health care dolar is being spent and whether Americans are getting quality care for money spent
